comment._content: Beautiful photo of young girl riding bare back on a horse.

comment._content: nice photo, but she is not bare back , you can clearly see stirrups saddle flap and girth.

comment.author: 29079609@N02
comment._content: Harvey S. Ladew (1887 - 1976) was a noted American topiary and fox hunting enthusiast, who created the Ladew Topiary Gardens in Monkton, Maryland. You can see this horse has won a ribbon, on it's bridle.

comment.author: 35122993@N08
comment._content: nudecowboy: thanks for spotting the typo and providing the biographical information. We'll fix the typo and reload the description.

comment.author: 61361160@N00
comment._content: This photograph is featured in the Indicommons.org post The hills are alive, on one Flickr member's creative remix work.

comment.author: 70251312@N00
comment._content: LOC: Typo remains unfixed. Name is "Ladew," not "Cadew."

comment.author: 70251312@N00
comment._content: The whipped cream of New York society turned out in October, 1912, for the eleventh annual horse show at the Piping Rock Country Club, in Locust Valley, on the north shore of Long Island. A new clubhouse and stepped observation boxes had just been opened for their pleasure: Story in The New York Times, October 4, 1912: "SOCIETY AMATEURS IN THE SADDLE "Piping Rock Horse Show Attracts Hunting Set to Locust Valley Grounds" query.nytimes.com/mem/archive-free/pdf?res=9D06E1D6113BE6... Another story in The New York Times, October 5, 1912: "SOCIETY AIDS AT PIPING ROCK SHOW "Notable People View Amateur Horse Exhibition Amid Long Island Hills" query.nytimes.com/mem/archive-free/pdf?res=9506E6D7113AE6...
